content.text: What You Do Between the Dying

â€œDowntime between contracts is the contractorâ€™s responsibility. Time management, self-care, and professional development are not subsidized. Your next contract ping may arrive at any time. Be ready. Or donâ€™t. We have other contractors.â€œ
How Downtime Works
Between missions, contractors have open-ended downtime â€” days pass until the next contract arrives or the team decides to take one. Each day follows a simple structure:
The Day
Each day you have 4 Action Points (AP). You spend them on activities.
Sleep is mandatory. It costs 1 AP. You can skip it â€” but there are consequences.

That leaves 3 AP for productive activities each day. Some activities cost 1 AP (quick tasks), some cost 2 AP (half-day commitments), some cost 3 AP (full-day dedication). A few cost 4 AP (grueling ordeals that leave no time for anything else, including proper sleep).
The Economy of Time
Downtime is free in the sense that nobodyâ€™s shooting at you. It is not free in any other sense.

Living Costs: Every day of downtime costs credits just to exist. See the Cost of Living & Base of Operations document for full lifestyle tiers, mechanical effects, and the base-building system. Quick reference:
Lifestyle Cost/Day Key Effect HP Recovery/Day

Capsule 15 cr/day Neutral baseline. 2 HP Lockable storage.
Apartment 30 cr/day Standard comfort. 3 HP Gear storage. Workspace.
Upscale 75 cr/day +1 stress 4 HP + Grit bonus recovery. -2 toxicity/day. +1 social (corps).
Luxury 200 cr/day +2 stress Full HP (complete recovery. -3 recovery toxicity/day. +2 overnight) social. Full workshop. Visible.
Corporate 0 cr/day Free. Monitored. 3 HP (decent Housing -1 social (other facilities, no contractors). privacy) ----------------- ----------------- ----------------- -----------------
HP Recovery happens automatically with sleep. No check, no AP cost beyond the mandatory Sleep activity. You heal the listed amount per day.

A contractor at 5 HP in a Capsule takes 8 days to fully heal (16 HP recovered). At 15 cr/day, thatâ€™s 120 cr just to get back to fighting shape. The same contractor in Luxury heals overnight for 200 cr. The choice: slow and cheap, or fast and expensive. The economic pressure never stops, even when youâ€™re resting.
Grit bonus on Upscale: Your body heals faster in comfort. Add your Grit stat bonus to the 4 HP base. A Grit 4 contractor recovers 8 HP/day in Upscale housing.

Medicine skill bonus: If a crewmate with Medicine T2+ tends to you during downtime (costs them 1 AP), add +2 HP to your daily recovery regardless of lodging. The field medic earns their keep between missions too.

Living costs are paid daily. A contractor earning 500 cr per mission who takes 10 days of downtime at Apartment lifestyle spends 300 cr just existing. Thatâ€™s 60% of their pay gone before theyâ€™ve done anything productive. The grind doesnâ€™t stop between missions.
Breaking the cycle: Contractors who invest in a Base of Operations can eliminate daily housing costs entirely. See Cost of Living & Base of Operations for the full system.
Activities
ðŸ’¤ SLEEP (1 AP â€” Mandatory)
Sleep. Your body needs it. Most of it is chrome now, but the meat parts still dream.
Normal Sleep (1 AP): No penalties. Required daily. If you have the Genius trait, sleep clears 0 Stress (your brain doesnâ€™t stop).
Extended Rest (2 AP): Deep recovery sleep. Clear +1 Stress beyond normal rest activities. Good for Genius contractors or anyone running hot. But thatâ€™s half your productive day gone.
Skip Sleep (0 AP): You donâ€™t sleep. Gain +1 Stress. Gain the following cumulative penalties:

â€¢ 1 night skipped: -1 to all checks tomorrow. â€¢ 2 consecutive nights: -2 to all checks. Hallucinations begin (mild â€” GM describes unsettling details that may or may not be real). â€¢ 3 consecutive nights: -3 to all checks. Cannot distinguish hallucination from reality reliably. GM can insert one false detail per scene that your character believes is true. â€¢ 4+ consecutive nights: Roll 1d20 vs DC 10 each morning. Fail = you collapse. Unconscious for 12 hours. All skipped-sleep penalties clear but gain +2 Stress.

Certain augments/mutations may modify sleep requirements. Neural Hive users technically never fully sleep (the hive whispers). Genius contractors need +2 hours (built into the normal 1 AP cost, but Extended Rest is more valuable to them).
Study, practice, learn. AP cost depends on learning method.
Method AP Cost Effect
Self-Study 1 AP Roll for LP (see Learning System). Can do other things today.
Peer Learning 2 AP Roll for LP. Your teacher also spends 2 AP.
Instructor 2 AP Roll for LP. Pay 100 cr for the session.
Academy 3 AP Roll for LP (with advantage). Pay 250 cr. This is most of your day. ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------

Stress from learning: Each day spent on Skill Training (any method) gives +1 Stress to contractors with the Genius trait. Their brain doesnâ€™t distinguish â€œproductive learningâ€œ from â€œgrinding mental overload.â€œ Regular contractors donâ€™t gain stress from learning.

You can only make one learning roll per day regardless of AP remaining. Your brain needs time to consolidate. Spending 1 AP on Self-Study and then 1 AP on a different Self-Study for a different skill doesnâ€™t work â€” pick one skill per day.
Getting work done on your body. Chrome, mutations, scars.

Activity AP Cost Effect

Vice Dependency
(see below). Drinking, drugs, gambling, adrenaline-seeking. Fast relief. Risky habit. ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Vice Dependency
If you gain a Vice Dependency, it works like this:

â€¢ Each downtime period, you must spend at least 1 AP and 20 cr on your vice or gain +2 Stress.  â€¢ The vice still clears 2 Stress when indulged (it works â€” thatâ€™s why itâ€™s dangerous).  â€¢ To break a dependency: spend 3 consecutive downtime days without indulging (gaining +2 Stress each day = +6 Stress total over 3 days). After 3 days clean, the dependency breaks.  â€¢ A character can have multiple vices. They stack. This gets ugly fast.
Building relationships, gathering intel, maintaining contacts.
Activity AP Cost Details
Contact Maintenance 1 AP Spend time with an existing NPC contact. Keeps the relationship warm. Neglected contacts may become unreliable.
Networking 2 AP Attempt to establish a new contact. Negotiate or Streetwise check. Full success = reliable new contact. Partial = theyâ€™ll talk to you but donâ€™t trust you yet.
Intel Gathering 1 AP Ask around about a topic. Awareness or Streetwise check. Success = useful information. Partial = partial info or misleading info mixed with truth.

Reputation Building 1 AP Do something visible in the community. Help someone, show up somewhere, make a statement. Slowly builds street rep or corp rep (GM tracks). ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Long-term projects that donâ€™t fit other categories. These are player-driven goals the GM adjudicates.
Scale AP Cost Examples
Small 1 AP Write a letter, update your will, research a specific topic, maintain equipment
Medium 2 AP Modify your living space, set up a workshop, investigate a lead, plan a heist
Large 3 AP Build something significant, establish a business front, infiltrate an organization long-term ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Personal projects may require multiple days. GM tracks progress as needed â€” these are narrative, not mechanical.
Stress System (Consolidated)
Stress was introduced with the Genius trait, but it applies to ALL contractors. Genius contractors just accumulate it faster.
Stress Track
Max Stress: 6 for all contractors.
At max stress, you suffer a Breakdown (see below).
Stress Sources
Source Stress Gained Who
Skipping sleep +1 per night Everyone
Learning (any +1 per day of study Genius only method)
Witnessing ally hit 0 +1 per incident Genius only HP
Unsolvable problem +1 (once/session, GM Genius only discretion)
Critical failure on +1 Genius only any check
Dangerous Contract +1 Everyone (side work)
Black Market Ops +1 Everyone
Risky Gig (failed +1 Everyone roll)
Vice withdrawal +2 per day Dependent contractors (skipping vice when dependent)

Stress Recovery

Relaxation -1 1 AP

Natural recovery floor: Stress naturally decreases by 1 per day, but only if youâ€™re at Stress 3 or higher. Below 3, it doesnâ€™t passively decay â€” you have to actively recover. This means low-level stress lingers unless you spend AP on it, but high-level stress doesnâ€™t spiral infinitely if youâ€™re doing other things.
Breakdowns (6/6 Stress)
When stress hits 6, the contractor suffers a breakdown. Roll 1d6:
Roll Breakdown
1 Paralysis. Cannot act for 1 round in next combat. Analysis paralysis, frozen in place.
2 Hyperfocus. Obsess over one irrelevant detail for next scene. -2 to unrelated checks.
3 Dissociation. -2 to all social checks for 1 full day. Youâ€™re present but not here.
4 Insomnia Spiral. Sleep costs 2 AP for the next 3 days (body wonâ€™t shut down).
5 Emotional Bleed. Snap at an ally. Relationship strain. -1 to checks working with them for 1 day.

6 Clarity. (Genius only â€” others reroll.) Breakdown resolves into insight. Clear ALL stress. Gain +2 LP toward current skill. The worst result because it teaches you that burning out works. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
After breakdown: Stress resets to 3 (not 0). The pressure never fully disappears. A contractor who breaks down and doesnâ€™t actively recover will break down again in 3+ days.

Downtime Duration & Contract Pings
Downtime is open-ended. Days pass until:

1. The team decides to take a contract. Available contracts can be checked at any time (1 AP, or passively via notifications). 2. A contract pings the team. The GM sends a contract notification. The team can accept or decline â€” but declining has soft consequences: â€¢ First decline: No penalty. Contracts are voluntary. â€¢ Repeated declines: Contract quality degrades. Corps stop sending the good jobs. Pay drops. Eventually the only pings are the ones nobody else will take. 1. External events force action. Rent runs out. A debt comes due. Someone kicks in your door. The world doesnâ€™t pause just because youâ€™re resting.
The Economic Drain
Every day of downtime costs money just to exist:
Days Capsule Apartment Upscale (15/day) (30/day) (75/day)
3                 45 cr             90 cr             225 cr
5                 75 cr             150 cr            375 cr

A standard mission pays 400-600 cr. A contractor who takes 10 days of downtime at Apartment lifestyle spends 300 cr just on rent â€” before food, training, treatment, or any other activity. The math is always working against you.

This is the pacing mechanic. Players can take as much downtime as they want, but the economy ensures they canâ€™t rest forever. At some point, the money runs out and the next contract isnâ€™t optional anymore. The team doesnâ€™t need a GM to tell them downtime is over â€” their wallets do it for them.
Design Notes for GMs

Downtime is gameplay, not bookkeeping. Every AP spent should be a micro-scene or a decision point. The contractor studying at the academy â€” who else is there? The one doing manual labor â€” what do they overhear on the docks? The one visiting a contact â€” what does the contact want in return? Downtime is where characters become people.

Let the economy breathe. Donâ€™t rush players back to missions. The tension of watching credits tick down while you recover is the point. If theyâ€™re managing well, contracts should ping with interesting choices (safe + low pay vs. risky + high pay). If theyâ€™re desperate, the only contract available should be the one nobody wants.

Stress is the hidden clock. Players will optimize AP for maximum productivity and skip sleep/rest. Let them. Stress accumulates. Breakdowns happen at the worst times. The system self-corrects â€” the player who grinds every AP toward learning will eventually break down and lose more time than they saved. Sustainable pacing is rewarded mechanically.

Vice is a trap â€” a useful one. It clears 2 Stress for 1 AP, which is the best ratio in the game. But dependency is a 1-in-3 chance and once youâ€™re hooked, youâ€™re spending AP and credits every downtime period just to avoid withdrawal stress. Itâ€™s the fastest relief and the slowest prison. Let players discover this naturally.

Track time loosely. You donâ€™t need to play out every day of downtime in detail. Ask players what their daily routine looks like, resolve the important days in detail (installation day, training day, the day they got robbed), and summarize the rest. â€œYou spend 4 days at the academy, here are your rolls. You spend 2 days resting. On day 7, something happens.â€œ Keep it moving.

Contract pings are your pacing lever. If downtime is dragging, ping a contract. If players are enjoying the downtime RP, let it breathe. The beauty of open-ended downtime is that you control the gas pedal without an arbitrary timer. When the story needs to move, the phone rings.
